facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 8 of 1957 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPFLLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 8 of 1957.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated 30th August 1955 of Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 8 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated the 30th August, 1955, of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 8 of 1955 arising out of the judgment and order dated the 10th December, 1954, of the Single Judge of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ No. 1245 of 1954.

facts.text: Special Appeal No. 8 of 1955 arose out of judgment dated 10th December 1954 of Single Judge of Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ No. 1245 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated the 30th August, 1955, of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 8 of 1955 arising out of the judgment and order dated the 10th December, 1954, of the Single Judge of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ No. 1245 of 1954.

facts.text: Certificate granted by Allahabad High Court on February 3 1956 for appeal to Supreme Court under Art. 133(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: This appeal has been preferred to this Court on the strength of a certificate granted by the High Court of Allahabad on February 3, 1956, to the effect that the case is a fit one for appeal to the Supreme Court under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Relevant facts not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant facts, which are number number in dispute, are these.

facts.text: General election to the Municipal Board of Bareilly in October 1953.

anchor.surface_text: There was a general election to the Municipal 54 Board of Bareilly in October, 1953.

facts.text: Appellant Mangoo Singh and respondent No. 3 Imdad Husain were candidates from Ward No. 15.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, Mangoo Singh, and respondent No. 3, Imdad Husain, along with sever- al others, were candidates at the said election from Ward No. 15.

facts.text: Date fixed for filing nominations was October 5 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The date fixed for filing numberinations was October 5, 1953, and the date for scrutiny of the numberinations filed was October 7, 1953.

facts.text: Date for scrutiny of nominations was October 7 1953.

anchor.surface_text: and the date for scrutiny of the numberinations filed was October 7, 1953. The appellant and respondent No. 3 both filed their numberinations on the due date,

facts.text: Appellant and respondent No. 3 filed nominations on due date.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and respondent No. 3 both filed their numberinations on the due date, and at the time of scrutiny lmdad Husain raised an objection to the numberination of the appellant

facts.text: Imdad Husain raised objection at scrutiny to appellant's nomination on ground of disqualification under cl. g of s. 13-D due to arrears in municipal tax exceeding one year's demand.

anchor.surface_text: and at the time of scrutiny lmdad Husain raised an objection to the numberination of the appellant on the ground that the latter was disqualified under cl.  g  of s. 13-D of the Act for being chosen as a member of the said Municipal Board because he was in arrears in the payment of municipal tax in excess of one years demand.

facts.text: Objection dismissed and appellant's nomination accepted by Assistant Returning Officer.

anchor.surface_text: This objection was dismissed, and the numberination of the appellant was accepted by the Assistant Returning Officer.

facts.text: Poll took place on October 26 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The poll took place on October 26, 1953, and the companynting of votes was done on October 29, 1953.

facts.text: Counting of votes on October 29 1953.

anchor.surface_text: 1953, and the companynting of votes was done on October 29, 1953. Four persons were to be elected from the said Ward,

facts.text: Four persons to be elected from Ward No. 15; appellant third, Imdad Husain fifth.

anchor.surface_text: Four persons were to be elected from the said Ward, and the appellant was the third in the list by reason of the number of votes which he had obtained. Imdad Husain was fifth in the list.

facts.text: Appellant declared elected; Imdad Husain top unsuccessful candidate.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the appellant was declared as one of the returned candidates, and lmdad Husain was at the top of the unsuccessful candidates.

facts.text: Imdad Husain filed election petition to set aside appellant's election on ground of disqualification under cl. g s.13-D.

anchor.surface_text: lmdad Husain then filed an election petition to set aside the election of the present appellant on various grounds. The only ground with which we are number companycerned is the disqualification under cl.  g  of s. 13-D of the Act.

facts.text: Election Tribunal by judgment dated October 20 1954 held appellant disqualified under cl. g s.13-D due to arrears exceeding one year's demand; payment of Rs.115-3-0 on Oct 10 1953 did not wipe off disqualification.

anchor.surface_text: This election petition was heard by the Election Tribunal and by its judgment dated October 20, 1954, the Election Tribunal held that the appellant was in arrears in the payment of municipal tax in excess of one years demand to which s. 166 of the Act applied and, there- fore, came under the disqualification in cl.  g  of s. 13-D of the Act It further held that the payment of a sum of Rs. 115-3-0 on October 10, 1953,

facts.text: Election Tribunal held no bill presented under s.166 and no demand notice under s.168 served on appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It may be here stated that the Election Tribunal also held that numberbill for payment of the tax was presented to the appellant as required by s. 166, number was any demand numberice served on him as required by s. 168 of the Act.

facts.text: Election Tribunal set aside appellant's election and declared casual vacancy under cl. a sub-s.2 s.25; vacancy filled by election of third respondent on April 5 1955.

anchor.surface_text: On the above find- ings, the Tribunal allowed the election petition, set aside the election of the appellant and declared a casual vacancy under cl.  a  of sub-s.  2  of s. 25 of the Act, which vacancy was subsequently filled up by the election of the third respondent on April 5, 1955.

facts.text: Next general election in the Municipality due in October 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The next general elec- tion in the Municipality is due in October, 1957.

facts.text: Appellant moved Allahabad High Court for writ under Art.226 against Election Tribunal decision.

anchor.surface_text: Against the decision of the Election Tribunal, the appellant moved the High Court of Allahabad for the issue of a writ under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Chaturvedi J. dismissed the writ application agreeing with Election Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The main point urged by the appellant was that the Election Tribunal was in error in its interpretation of cl.  g  of s. 13-D of the Act. Cha- turvedi J. who dealt with the application of the appellant, agreed with the view of the law as expressed by the Election Tribunal and dismissed the application.

facts.text: Division Bench Agarwala and Sahai JJ. dismissed appeal by judgment dated August 30 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then preferred an appeal to a Division Bench of the said High Court. This appeal was also dismissed by Agarwala and Sahai JJ. by their judgment dated August 30, 1955.

facts.text: Appellant paid Rs. 115-3-0 on October 10 1953.

anchor.surface_text: the payment of a sum of Rs. 115-3-0 on October 10, 1953, five days after the date fixed for the filing of numberinations, did number wipe off that dis- qualification,
under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution.

concepts.unlisted_description: Governing statute for municipal elections and disqualifications

anchor.surface_text: Representation of the People Act, 1951

issues.text: What is the true scope, meaning and effect of cl. g of s. 13-D of the U. P. Municipalities Act, 1916?

anchor.surface_text: The question that falls for decision is the true scope, meaning and effect of cl, g of s. 13-D of the U. P. Municipalities Act, 1916  U. P. II of 1916 , hereinafter referred to as the Act.

issues.text: Whether the disqualification under cl. g of s. 13-D operates with reference to the date of poll or the date of filing nomination (due to the expression 'for being chosen as')?

anchor.surface_text: The first contention of learned counsel for the appellant relates to and arises out of the expression for being chosen as occurring in the section. The argument is this. It is submitted that a person is chosen as a member of a board when the poll takes place and a majority of voters vote for him as their chosen candidate therefore, the relevant date for the operation of the disqualification is the date of the poll...

issues.text: Whether the disqualification under cl. g of s. 13-D, which ceases under the second proviso upon payment of arrears, operates retrospectively to validate a nomination filed while disqualified?

anchor.surface_text: We now turn to the second proviso to s. 13-D. The submission of learned counsel for the appellant is that, as stated in the proviso, the disqualification is transient and ceases to operate as soon as the arrears are paid On October 10, 1953, the appellant was no longer disqualified and, therefore, he could be chosen on the date of the poll...

issues.text: Whether the arrears in cl. g of s. 13-D 'to which section 166 applies' require actual presentation of a bill under s. 166 and service of a demand notice under s. 168?

arguments.claim: Appellant disqualified under cl. g of s. 13-D due to arrears in municipal tax exceeding one year's demand

arguments.claim: Appellant in arrears exceeding one year's demand to which s.166 applies, hence disqualified under cl. g s.13-D; payment on Oct 10 1953 did not wipe off disqualification

arguments.claim: Relevant date for disqualification under cl. g is date of poll, not nomination, due to 'for being chosen as'; paid arrears before poll so not disqualified

anchor.surface_text: The first contention of learned counsel for the appellant relates to and arises out of the expression for being chosen as occurring in the section. The argument is this. It is submitted that a person is chosen as a member of a board when the poll takes place and a majority of voters vote for him as their chosen candidate therefore, the relevant date for the operation of the disqualification is the date of the poll...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: quired by s. 168 of the Act. As on the finding of the Election Tribu- nal neither a bill was presented to the appellant, number was he served with a d

arguments.court_reasoning: Identical expression in Art.102, RPA s.7; precedents Chatturbhuj Vithaldas, Ponnuswami; election continuous process starting at nomination; para 22(2) election order

arguments.claim: Disqualification under proviso to cl. g is transient and ceases upon payment before poll; has retrospective effect to validate nomination filed while disqualified

anchor.surface_text: We now turn to the second proviso to s. 13-D. The submission of learned counsel for the appellant is that, as stated in the proviso, the disqualification is transient and ceases to operate as soon as the arrears are paid On October 10, 1953, the appellant was no longer disqualified and, therefore, he could be chosen on the date of the poll...

court_response_anchor.surface_text: cause to be served upon the person liable for the payment of the said sum a numberice of demand in the form set forth in schedule IV, or to the like

arguments.court_reasoning: No retrospective effect; precedents Ahmed Hossain (Bengal Municipal Act), Harford v Linskey (Municipal Corporations Act); avoids uncertainty in election process

arguments.claim: 'to which s.166 applies' and 'demand' in cl. g require actual bill presentation under s.166 and demand notice under s.168; neither done so no disqualification
arguments.court_reasoning: Expression describes nature/type of dues (taxes etc. listed in s.166(1)); 'demand' means dues/claim, not requiring notice; contextual interpretation

arguments.claim: Disqualification under cl. g attaches at date of nomination as part of continuous election process; 'for being chosen as' refers to nomination stage

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this argument. It is worthy of note that an identical expression shall be disqualified for being chosen as occurs in Art. 102 of the Constitution and s. 7 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951. This expression occurring in s. 7 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, was considered by this Court in Chatturbhuj Vithaldas Jasani v. Moreshwar Parashram...

arguments.claim: Second proviso does not have retrospective effect; disqualification at nomination persists despite later payment
'to which s.166 applies' qualifies nature of arrears (taxes/dues listed in s.166(1)); 'demand' means mere dues, not requiring procedural notice under s.168

holdings.text: If a person is disqualified on the date of nomination, he cannot be chosen as a candidate because the disqualification mentioned in s. 13-D attaches to him on that date.

anchor.surface_text: If a person is disqualified on the date of nomination, he cannot be chosen as a candidate because the disqualification mentioned in s. 13-D attaches to him on that date. This is also clear from para. 22 2  of the U. P. Municipali-

holdings.reasoning_summary: Identical expression 'disqualified for being chosen as' in Art.102 Constitution and s.7 RPA 1951; precedents Chatturbhuj Vithaldas Jasani and N.P. Ponnuswami hold nomination crucial date in continuous election process; para 22(2) election order requires scrutiny at nomination.

holdings.text: The wiping off of the disqualification under the second proviso has no retrospective effect, and the disqualification which subsisted on the day of filing nominations did not cease to subsist on that day by reason of a subsequent payment of the arrears of municipal tax.

anchor.surface_text: This argument also we cannot accept as correct it is really the first argument in a different form. The wiping off of the disqualification under the second proviso has no retrospective effect, and the disqual- ification which subsisted on the day of filing nominations

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso cessation not retrospective; precedents Ahmed Hossain v. Aswini Kumar (Bengal Municipal Act) and Harford v. Linskey (Municipal Corporations Act); avoids uncertainty and confusion in election process if disqualification removed mid-process.

holdings.text: The expression to which s. 166 applies merely describes the nature of the demand referred to in cl. g.

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of the view that the expression to which s. 166 applies cannot bear the meaning sought to be given to it on behalf of the appellant. That expression merely describes the nature of the demand referred to in cl. g . Section 166 refers to three types

holdings.reasoning_summary: Phrase qualifies type of dues (taxes, water charges etc. listed in s.166(1)(a)-(c)); not requiring actual bill presentation; contextual and harmonious construction.

holdings.text: The word demand in cl. g does not attract operation of s.168 and means mere claim or dues in excess of one year's municipal tax or other dues.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Contextual meaning from surrounding words 'arrears in payment of... in excess of one years demand'; dictionary allows 'claim or due' without requiring notice; unnecessary to invoke s.168 procedure.

holdings.text: None of the contentions urged on behalf of the appellant is worthy of acceptance. The election petition was rightly decided, as the appellant was disqualified for being chosen as a member of the Municipal Board in question on the day he filed his nomination, under cl. g of s. 13-D of the Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects all three contentions on construction of cl.g s.13-D; applies to accepted facts of arrears on nomination date (Oct 5, 1953), payment after (Oct 10); affirms lower courts.

precedents.citation: Chatturbhuj Vithaldas Jasani v. Moreshwar Parashram and Others 1954 S.C.R. 817, 821

anchor.surface_text: Chatturbhuj Vithaldas Jasani v. Moreshwar Parashram and Others 1

precedents.case_name: Chatturbhuj Vithaldas Jasani v. Moreshwar Parashram and Others
precedents.cited_proposition: the date for putting in the nominations was one of the crucial dates; the words 'shall be disqualified for being chosen' refer to the process starting with nomination
precedents.cited_holding: Now the words of the section are shall be disqualified for being chosen. The choice is made by a series of steps starting with the nomination and ending with the announcement of the election. It follows that if a disqualification attaches to a candidate at any one of these stages, he cannot be chosen.

precedents.citation: N. P. Ponnuswami v. The Returning Officer, Namakkal Constituency and Others 1952 S.C.R. 218

anchor.surface_text: N. P. Ponnuswami v. The Returning Officer, Namakkal Constituency and Others 1

precedents.case_name: N. P. Ponnuswami v. The Returning Officer, Namakkal Constituency and Others
precedents.cited_proposition: election is a continuous process consisting of several stages and embracing many steps of which nomination is one; nomination is the foundation of a candidate's right to go to the polls and must be treated as an integral part of the election

precedents.citation: Ahmed Hossain v. Aswini Kumar A.I.R. 1953 Cal. 542

anchor.surface_text: Ahmed Hossain v. Aswini Kumar 1

precedents.cited_proposition: if a person was disqualified on the date of nomination he could not shake off his pre-existing disqualification by acquiring a new right between the date of nomination and the date of scrutiny
precedents.cited_holding: if a person was disqualified on the date of the nomination, he could not shake off his pre-existing disqualification by acquiring a new right between the date of nomination and the date of scrutiny

anchor.surface_text: Harford v. Linskey 1

precedents.cited_proposition: a person, who at the time of nomination is disqualified for election, is disqualified also for nomination; nomination is an essential part of the election
precedents.cited_holding: in cases of elections under the Municipal Corporations Acts a person, who at the time of nomination is disqualified for election in the manner in which this petitioner was disqualified, is disqualified also for nomination. The nomination is for this purpose an essential part of the election
